history.content: I'd say Math 53 is important to learn about partial derivatives, gradients, and multivariate differentiation (which is useful in optimization/ML), and the multivariate integration part of the class is useful in continuous probability (also used in 126/189/70). You could probably get by with self-study, but taking the class is useful in my opinion.

children.subject:
It depends on what you're interested in. If you are mainly SWE-minded, they aren't really useful. If you are ML, EE, robotics, etc. then they are. 

Another thing to be aware of is that you can now use 53 to cover 3 units of the UD tech elective requirement, so you would gain at least that by taking it. If you are interested in a bunch of other courses for which it isn't relevant, then don't take it. Also, since you took 16A and will have to take 16B at some point, you don't need to take 54. I hear 54 does a better and more thorough job at teaching you the math concepts than 16A/B does, but this is not all that important for some CS topics. If you feel like after 16A/B that you still really want your linear algebra to be solid, you can just take Math 110 or self-study stuff you had trouble with.

history.content:
How important is knowledge from Math 53 and 54 for upper-division CS classes other than 189? I'm just sketching out my 4-year plan and I'm on the fence of adding them into my schedule. I'm taking EE 16A right now and did not have the best time understanding the linear algebra. I can definitely self study both math courses over time as I have the textbooks and syllabi but I don't know if its worth to take these classes in person. 

I'm an intended CS major on track to declare. 

Thanks in advance for feedback!
history.subject: Importance of Math 53 and Math 54?
